This year and now Murphy Brown is back Twenty years after the Emmy winning sitcom went off the air CBS has revived it for an eleventh season Candice Bergen plays the older but still fast talking broadcast journalist who returns alongside the original cast NPR TV critic Eric Deggans joins us to talk about it I Eric
Hey so Murphy Brown was always about mining politics for entertainment back in the day I'd had fans from both sides of the aisle Senator Orrin hatch Republican of Utah even sending a head shot hoping to make a guest appearance [laughter] do you think it could have crossover appeal today or are they even making an effort no [laughter]
In one word or you know I spoke to the show's creator and show runner Diane English in LA in July
And basically she told me she didn't think they would be a show 'em there would be a revival or if if Trump hadn't been elected president um she was a how supportive of Hillary Clinton ran a pack 'em
Huge party at our house ah ah for the election
And had like two hundred bottles of champagne that she could no open when a Hillary Clinton didn't win and so uh seeing how they affect the Trump has had on politics on media especially ah she's got this show that features these people were supposed to be top journalist
So of course pushing back against that has become one of the major themes in the revival of of Murphy Brown
And because she's so close to Hillary Clinton of course she uh she got the former secretary of state or to actually may an appearance on the show so we've got a clip of that uh let's let's
Let's say and I also see you've had previous secretarial which theory absolutely for four years I was the secretary [noise]
I was a secretary at a very large Oregon [noise] and you have all the records at skills computer nail emails [noise]
I I Do have some experience with [noise]
Always makes you wonder if there's nothing I again
I get out [laughter] no I doubt it I don't think they would have brought up emails editor right um it ... you know Hillary Clinton has been having some fun she was she is also appeared in a an episode of Madam Secretary that trauma
Um alongside Colin Powell and I'm I'm a ... and uh other political so
I'm ... this show has been very much about pushing back against Trump ism the Murphy Brown revival
And I'm In an in an episode um that just stared you know she sneaks into the White House briefing room and sort of pushes back against some of the things they do so this shows very much about pushing back against Trump ism and pushing back against the monitor shape with a GOP so it it is not a bipartisan
Now the original Murphy Brown went to war with Dan Quayle remember him a in a real life meets fiction moment during the Nineteen Ninety two presidential election Quayle made of family values speech where he criticized the character Murphy Brown
For having a child outside of marriage then the character Murphy round responded to quilt criticisms in the show and now it seems like the show is trying to manufacture that same dynamic with President Trump
Yeah there there's a a there was a scene towards the end of the first episode of the revival where Trump was supposedly watching these fictional uh news characters on the air and tweeting about them and then they were reading the tweets in them responding to him I think
We have a [noise] whole
Murphy you get back in time or oh you were wearing a hat
On [noise]
[laughter]
So of course a reference to wear a Murphy actually a limited very if of effective response to Dan Quayle back in the heyday of the show
I think it was interesting to me I'm a you know I had mixed feelings about this a revival I I did I found some of the humor to be I'm kind of old fashioned and and some of the speech fined by the Murphy Brown character to be kind of a dye tactic
And in your face in a way that that uh that wasn't necessarily entertaining and and this bit at the end of the first episode of the revival felt like wishful thinking in a way like
Like you like you you like it kind of wish the show I'm ... these people making a kind of wish to show would be impactful enough
That Donald Trump would actually watch it in sort of tweeted them
A while I was going on so uh so they actually made it happen within the confines of the show but um what's really happening is that there are so many people that have been saying things like this for so long on TV including most of the late night comedians that we have you know Stephen ... Jimmy Kimmel and
Ah Trevor Noah that uh it doesn't really feel like Murphy Brown is saying anything new um when when the show was originally doing this kind of commentary a gift
We're talking this way and there weren't a lot of sitcoms that were caught talking very directly about things that were happening in the world now all of that has changed and I think a swift Murphy Brown feeling a little out of step with the times
Well what about the idea also that this is yet another TV network show that is going for the ... factor and bring back something that was there before
Yeah um I mean in in a way this could feel like a like a step too far uh some some of the other ... boots I'm from the way the viewers responded to them you had a sense that there was sort of a open up demand amongst fans when Roseanne came back
Whatever you think of stars and bars politics um there's the audience responded by paying attention to the show and you had a sense that
Uh fans had kind of missed it and and with will and grace on NBC that revival the same thing now CBS is a little difference CBS has done a lot of revivals of shows
That are sort of thinly veiled a revival is you know they have a magnum PI they have swat they have mcgyver and all of these are just kind of an excuse to take really predictable and run of the mill a procedural adventure stories and and and slapped the veneer of the show a over it so
I'm a you know those have been under the radar in a way to get decent ratings but they're not the kind of phenomenon that will and grace
And um and and Roseanne where I think CBS was trying to do that kind of phenomenon with Murphy Brown but the show had minutes syndication for a long time so ah you know I don't think a lot of younger people leave a familiar with the show and because the the the ... version of it
I'm Still a little awkward and kind of old school I I think it's going to have a hard time finding new fans

But the allegations of drinking and sexual misconduct lobbed at Kavanaugh has prompted soul searching at the kinds of elite prep school he attended ... decades ago colleges have been taking a hard look at
How they may have committed a culture of drinking and sexual misconduct most has changed significantly since back then but as NPR's Tovia Smith reports some say there's still a ways to go
To many alumni of elite prep schools the picture Christine Blasey Ford painted up the drunken debauchery she encountered as a student is painfully familiar
I was deeply shaken and I just posted as anybody else having these really bad memories come up
Alexandra less God's graduated from the national cathedral school in Nineteen eighty eight with many memories she wishes she could forget
There was a drunk girl in a room um and there was a boy in there with her and there were other boys lined up outside the door and my friend recalls hearing I'm next time next
It was such a toxic culture of power and privilege she says many guys didn't even try to hide it and schools knew how bad it was in Nineteen Ninety the Washington Post reported that seven of them including Georgetown Prep work Kavanaugh went
Centered joint warning to parents about the excessive drinking and sex ed unsupervised parties
They called it a recipe for disaster
Georgetown ... current president declined to comment but in a recent letter to parents see bad to reevaluate school culture and to quote work with the guys on respect for women John Paul free is headed school at Philips Academy in Andover, Massachusetts
This has been a call to every educator I think and I think any school that isn't some gauge to him soul searching those making a mistake schools
Already changed dramatically since the eighties Paul for he says drift
Large stand by a student body that's no longer so exclusively the privileged and powerful and he says students are now schools on what he calls a culture of consent and respect
It is changing but it's still a problem on campuses and I certainly can't say that we are out of the woods yet

Well right as you mentioned it was below estimates are the economists in ah the Bloomberg survey had forecast about a hundred and eighty five thousand jobs so this is about fifty thousand below that but it's a very tough month
To get right because of Hurricane Florence um you know a lot of companies
That might have been planning to hire would postpone it and a lot of companies were just you know more or less laying people off temporarily because of the weather so they're actually about three hundred thousand people a away from work to do the bad weather

Um and it just does not show any signs of slowing down at the moment
